constructs.name: engineering_self_efficacy
constructs.description: The subjective feeling of being a competent, capable engineer who can handle technical challenges

constructs.name: technical_mastery_experiences
constructs.description: Successfully solving technical problems, debugging issues, implementing solutions effectively

constructs.name: peer_recognition
constructs.description: Receiving acknowledgment from colleagues - being sought for advice, positive code reviews, being seen as capable

constructs.name: task_achievement
constructs.description: Completing meaningful work units - shipping features, finishing projects, meeting milestones

constructs.name: skill_growth_perception
constructs.description: Awareness of learning and improvement over time - feeling that skills are developing

constructs.name: impostor_feelings
constructs.description: Self-doubt about one's abilities, feeling like a fraud despite evidence of competence

constructs.name: flow_state_engagement
constructs.description: Deep absorption in challenging but achievable technical work, losing track of time

constructs.name: social_comparison
constructs.description: Perception of one's abilities relative to engineering peers - favorable vs unfavorable comparisons

constructs.name: deliberate_practice
constructs.description: Intentional activities to build engineering skills beyond normal work requirements

constructs.name: cognitive_resources
constructs.description: Available mental energy, focus, and clarity for complex technical work

constructs.name: work_engagement
constructs.description: Motivation, involvement, and enthusiasm for engineering work

constructs.name: collaboration_quality
constructs.description: Quality of interactions with teammates - productive discussions, knowledge sharing, mutual support

constructs.name: learning_activities
constructs.description: Time and effort spent on learning new technical skills, concepts, or tools

constructs.name: problem_skill_match
constructs.description: How well the challenge level of assigned work matches current ability level

constructs.name: quality_feedback_received
constructs.description: Specific, constructive feedback on work quality from managers or peers

constructs.name: work_autonomy
constructs.description: Control and discretion over how engineering work is approached and executed

constructs.name: workload_stress
constructs.description: Pressure and strain from the amount of work relative to capacity

constructs.name: positive_affect
constructs.description: Daily emotional state - feeling good, optimistic, energized

constructs.name: years_of_experience
constructs.description: Total accumulated time working as an engineer

constructs.name: neuroticism
constructs.description: Personality trait reflecting tendency toward negative emotions, anxiety, and self-doubt

constructs.name: conscientiousness
constructs.description: Personality trait reflecting tendency toward diligence, organization, and goal pursuit

constructs.name: growth_mindset
constructs.description: Belief that engineering abilities can be developed through effort and learning

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality of rest and sleep recovery

constructs.name: team_psychological_safety
constructs.description: Perceived safety to take interpersonal risks, ask questions, and make mistakes on the team

constructs.name: manager_support
constructs.description: Quality of support, guidance, and advocacy from one's engineering manager

constructs.name: mentorship_access
constructs.description: Availability and quality of guidance from more senior engineers

constructs.name: organizational_learning_culture
constructs.description: Company culture that values continuous learning, experimentation, and growth

constructs.name: workload_demands
constructs.description: Volume and urgency of assigned work tasks and project deadlines

edges.description: Successfully solving technical problems directly builds confidence in one's engineering abilities (Bandura's mastery experiences)
External validation from respected colleagues confirms one's competence (social persuasion)
Completing meaningful work provides tangible evidence of capability
Perceiving that one is learning and improving supports belief in competence trajectory
Self-doubt and feeling like a fraud undermines belief in one's competence
Experiencing flow signals that one's skills are well-matched to challenges
How one perceives oneself relative to peers affects competence beliefs (vicarious experience)
Constructive feedback helps calibrate and build confidence in specific skills
Mental clarity and focus enable better problem-solving and debugging
Appropriately challenging work allows for successful completion
Skill-building activities improve ability to solve technical problems
Freedom to approach problems in preferred ways facilitates mastery
Accumulated experience provides pattern recognition and problem-solving frameworks
Completing work successfully leads to recognition from teammates
Good collaboration makes contributions visible and builds reputation
Demonstrated technical skill leads others to seek advice and acknowledge expertise
Psychologically safe teams are more likely to openly acknowledge contributions
Successfully solving technical problems leads to task completion
Higher engagement drives focus and persistence toward completing work
Available mental energy enables productive work completion
Excessive workload pressure interferes with ability to complete tasks well
Optimal challenge-skill balance is the core condition for flow
Mental clarity and focus are prerequisites for entering flow
Intrinsic motivation increases likelihood of flow experiences
Stress and pressure disrupt the focused attention needed for flow
Tendency toward anxiety and self-doubt amplifies impostor experiences
Unfavorable social comparisons fuel feelings of being a fraud
Success experiences counter impostor feelings over time
External validation reduces self-doubt about competence
Engaging in learning creates awareness of acquiring new knowledge
Intentional practice produces noticeable skill development
Successfully handling challenges reveals capability growth
Mentors help recognize and articulate growth in skills
Feedback highlights areas of improvement and growth
Good sleep restores mental energy and focus capacity
Chronic stress depletes cognitive resources and focus
Positive emotional state supports broader attention and cognitive flexibility
Positive mood increases motivation and involvement in work
Control over work increases intrinsic motivation per self-determination theory
Flow experiences are intrinsically rewarding and boost subsequent engagement
Supportive managers foster motivation and commitment to work
Feeling competent increases willingness to engage with challenging work
Believing abilities can develop motivates intentional skill-building
Diligence and goal-orientation drive consistent practice behaviors
Engaged workers invest more in developing their skills
Mentors guide what to practice and provide structure for improvement
Culture that values learning encourages investment in skill development
Supportive managers provide time and resources for learning
Conscientious individuals pursue self-improvement more consistently
Perceiving growth reinforces and motivates continued learning
Being recognized shifts comparison toward more favorable perception
Success provides evidence for favorable peer comparison
More experience provides realistic peer reference points
High neuroticism biases toward unfavorable upward comparisons
Feeling competent contributes to positive emotional state
Good sleep supports positive mood regulation
Excessive stress depletes positive emotional resources
Completing meaningful work generates positive emotions
Safety to take risks enables open, productive collaboration
Positive mood facilitates better interpersonal interactions
Engaged workers invest more in collaborative relationships
Experience builds skills that match to more work challenges
Practice builds skills that match to assigned challenges
Good managers assign appropriately challenging work
More autonomy provides control that buffers against stress
Higher volume and urgency of work increases experienced stress
Supportive managers provide constructive, specific feedback
Safe environments enable honest, helpful feedback exchange
Good collaboration includes helpful peer feedback
More experienced engineers typically receive greater autonomy
Supportive managers grant appropriate autonomy

indicators.name: technical_search_sophistication
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate each entry's technical sophistication: 0=not a technical search/visit, 1=basic syntax or beginner concepts ('how to write for loop', 'what is an array'), 2=standard implementation ('sort array python', 'connect to database'), 3=design patterns or architecture ('repository pattern', 'microservices communication'), 4=advanced optimization or debugging ('memory leak detection', 'performance profiling'), 5=expert or cutting-edge topics ('CRDT algorithms', 'distributed consensus').

indicators.name: confident_query_indicator
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search query is direct and specific without struggle language, showing confidence (e.g., 'python datetime formatting', 'react useEffect cleanup'). 0 if query contains uncertainty markers ('not working', 'help please', 'why doesn't', 'still getting error') or is vague.

indicators.name: solution_resource_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting a solution-providing resource: Stack Overflow answer page (URL contains '/a/' or 'accepted answer'), GitHub code examples, official documentation with implementation samples, or tutorial completion pages. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: implementation_focused_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search indicates building/implementing: contains 'how to implement', 'example', 'create', 'build', or seeks working code. 0 if search is troubleshooting failure ('error', 'not working', 'failed') or non-technical.

indicators.name: code_review_platform_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting code review platforms where peer recognition occurs: GitHub pull request pages, GitLab merge requests, Gerrit reviews, Phabricator differentials, or code review dashboards. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: professional_community_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting professional community platforms: LinkedIn (especially notifications or profile views), dev.to, HackerNews user pages, Twitter/X tech community, or tech forums where recognition is visible. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: completion_signal_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visit/search indicates task completion: CI/CD pipeline success pages, deployment dashboards, merged PR confirmation, release notes, production monitoring, or search contains 'deploy', 'ship', 'release', 'launch'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: milestone_page_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting pages showing completed work: closed GitHub issues, merged pull requests, completed Jira/Linear tickets, or project milestone pages showing completion status. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: new_technology_learning_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this entry indicates learning a new technology: search contains 'learn', 'tutorial', 'introduction to', 'getting started', 'beginner guide', or visits first-time learning resources for a framework/language. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: advanced_topic_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if content covers advanced topics indicating skill growth: system design, architecture patterns, performance optimization, security best practices, or cutting-edge technologies. 0 for basic/intermediate content.

indicators.name: impostor_syndrome_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search contains self-doubt terms: 'impostor syndrome', 'not good enough engineer', 'everyone knows more than me', 'feel like fraud', 'am I qualified', 'should I be in tech', 'not smart enough'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: insecure_basic_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if searching basic concepts with insecurity markers: contains 'dumb question', 'should know this', 'basic X explained', 'embarrassed to ask', or searches for very fundamental concepts an engineer should know. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: focus_supporting_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting content supporting sustained focus: detailed documentation pages, in-depth technical articles, code repository deep-dives, book chapters, or long-form tutorials. 0 for quick lookups, social media, or shallow content.

indicators.name: distraction_content_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting distraction content: social media (Twitter/X, Facebook, Instagram, Reddit non-technical subs), entertainment news, non-educational YouTube, games, shopping, or casual browsing unrelated to work. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: career_comparison_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search involves peer comparison: salary comparisons, 'engineer levels', 'how long to become senior', LinkedIn browsing of other engineers' profiles, 'X years experience should I know', career progression timelines. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: benchmark_platform_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting career/salary comparison platforms: levels.fyi, Glassdoor salary pages, Blind app, Comparably, or tech career ladder discussion threads. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: practice_platform_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting deliberate coding practice platforms: LeetCode, HackerRank, Codewars, Exercism, Project Euler, CodeSignal, AlgoExpert, or algorithm/data structure practice sites. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: structured_course_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting structured learning platforms with courses: Coursera, Udemy, edX, Pluralsight, LinkedIn Learning, freeCodeCamp, Codecademy, or similar systematic curriculum-based learning. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: reactive_error_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search appears to be copy-pasted error message or stack trace: contains file paths, line numbers, exact error codes, long technical error strings, or unedited exception messages suggesting reactive debugging without comprehension. 0 for formulated queries.

indicators.name: systematic_query_indicator
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search/visit shows systematic approach: well-formulated specific queries, official documentation visits, authoritative technical sources, or clear research progression. 0 for vague, scattered, or panicked searches.

indicators.name: work_related_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this entry is work or engineering related: technical documentation, Stack Overflow, GitHub, development tools, programming searches, work applications. 0 for personal entertainment, social media, or unrelated content.

indicators.name: active_problem_solving_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if entry indicates active coding work: debugging searches, implementation questions, API documentation lookups, code-level problem solving, or technical solution seeking. 0 for passive reading, browsing, or non-coding activities.

indicators.name: collaboration_tool_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting team collaboration tools: Slack, Microsoft Teams, Discord (work), Notion, Confluence, Google Docs/Sheets (shared), Figma, Miro, or video conferencing links (Zoom, Meet). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: collaborative_discussion_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting collaborative technical discussions: GitHub PR comment threads, GitLab MR discussions, RFC documents, design doc comments, or team wiki edits with multiple contributors visible. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: documentation_tutorial_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting learning resources: official language/framework documentation, MDN, programming tutorials, 'Learn X in Y Minutes', technical wikis, or educational guides. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: concept_learning_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search shows learning intent: contains 'what is', 'how does X work', 'explain', 'tutorial', 'guide', 'introduction to', 'X vs Y' comparison for understanding, or 'why does X'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: challenge_level_rating
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate the challenge level relative to typical software engineer: 0=not technical, 1=too basic (trivial syntax lookup), 2=somewhat easy, 3=appropriate challenge level, 4=stretching but achievable, 5=highly challenging advanced topic.

indicators.name: frustration_struggle_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search shows struggle/frustration: contains 'still not working', 'tried everything', 'please help', 'why won't', 'hours stuck on', or shows desperate reformulations of same problem. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: review_feedback_page_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting pages displaying feedback: GitHub PR review comments section, GitLab MR feedback threads, Gerrit review comments, or performance review platforms showing actual feedback content. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: feedback_improvement_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if searching about processing feedback: 'code review best practices', 'responding to code review', 'how to improve from feedback', 'learning from PR comments'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: alternative_comparison_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search compares alternatives showing autonomous decision-making: 'X vs Y', 'alternatives to X', 'best approach for', 'should I use X or Y', 'pros and cons of'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: proactive_exploration_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visit shows proactive exploration beyond immediate requirements: researching new tools, exploring architectural improvements, investigating better approaches, or self-directed technical research. 0 for purely reactive problem-solving.

indicators.name: off_hours_work_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this is work-related technical content AND timestamp falls between 10pm-6am, indicating work spillover into rest hours. 0 if during normal hours or non-work content.

indicators.name: stress_burnout_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search contains stress/burnout terms: 'burnout', 'work stress', 'overwhelmed at work', 'too much work', 'work life balance', 'exhausted', 'overworked'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: positive_leisure_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting positive leisure content suggesting good mood: entertainment, music streaming, travel planning, hobby sites, sports, restaurants, vacation research, or feel-good content. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: negative_mood_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search indicates negative affect: 'feeling depressed', 'anxiety', 'feeling sad', 'lonely', mental health crisis resources, or mood-related health searches. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: sleep_problem_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to sleep issues: 'insomnia', 'can't sleep', 'sleep quality', 'tired all the time', 'melatonin', 'sleep apnea', 'sleep tracker', 'sleep schedule'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: late_night_activity_indicator
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if any activity (work or personal) occurs between 12am-5am based on entry timestamp, suggesting disrupted sleep patterns. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: psychological_safety_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to team psychological safety: 'psychological safety', 'afraid to speak up', 'fear of asking questions at work', 'blameless culture', 'team trust', 'safe to fail'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: team_conflict_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to team interpersonal issues: 'difficult coworker', 'team conflict', 'toxic team', 'disagreement at work', 'passive aggressive colleague', 'team dysfunction'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: manager_interaction_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to manager relationships: '1:1 meeting with manager', 'talking to boss', 'manager feedback', 'bad manager', 'good manager traits', 'managing up'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: management_content_visit
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting content about engineering management or manager-employee dynamics: engineering manager blogs, leadership articles, manager relationship advice, or management best practices. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: mentorship_seeking_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to mentorship: 'find mentor', 'engineering mentor', 'career guidance', 'mentorship program', 'how to get mentored', 'need career advice'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: senior_engineer_advice_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visiting senior engineer guidance content: staff/principal engineer blogs, tech lead advice, career advice from experienced engineers, or senior developer podcasts/talks. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: learning_culture_search
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if search relates to organizational learning: 'hackathon', 'tech talks', 'learning budget', 'conference attendance', 'company training', 'engineering culture'. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: exploratory_innovation_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if exploring emerging technologies beyond immediate work needs: new frameworks, industry trends, experimental tools, emerging tech (AI/ML trends, new languages), or innovation-focused content. 0 for routine work searches.

indicators.name: work_activity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this entry is any work-related activity: technical searches, documentation, development tools, work communication, or professional content. 0 for personal/leisure content.

indicators.name: weekend_work_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if this is work-related technical activity AND the entry timestamp is on Saturday or Sunday, indicating workload extending into weekends. 0 otherwise.
